,10.326320973056795,18.960222426826906,0.4209652227208921,0.05798849324818601,['Rhode Island Question 1, Constitutional Convention Question (2024)', 'Rhode Island Question 2, Higher Education Facilities Bond Measure (2024)', 'Rhode Island Question 3, Housing Acquisition, Development, and Infrastructure Bond Measure (2024)', 'Rhode Island Question 4, Environmental and Recreational Infrastructure Bond Measure (2024)', 'Rhode Island Question 5, Cultural Arts and Economy Grant Program Bond Measure (2024)']","['“Shall there be a convention to amend or revise the Constitution?[4]”', '“HIGHER EDUCATION FACILITIES - $160,500,000 
For capital improvements to higher education facilities, to be allocated as follows: 
a. University of Rhode Island Biomedical Sciences Building - $87,500,000 
b. Rhode Island College Cybersecurity Building - $73,000,000[4]”', '“HOUSING AND COMMUNITY OPPORTUNITY - $120,000,000 
To increase the availability of housing, support community revitalization, and promote home ownership, to be allocated as follows: 
a. Affordable Housing - $80,000,000 
b. Acquisition and Revitalization - $10,000,000 
c. Homeownership - $20,000,000 
d. Site Acquisition - $5,000,000 
e. Housing Related Infrastructure - $4,000,000 
f. Municipal Planning - $1,000,000[4]”', '“GREEN ECONOMY BONDS - $53,000,000 
For environmental and recreational purposes, to be allocated as follows: 
a. Port of Davisville Infrastructure at Quonset - $15,000,000 
b. Climate Resiliency - $2,000,000 
c. Brownfields Remediation and Economic Development - $5,000,000 
d. Local Recreation Projects - $5,000,000 e. Municipal Resiliency - $10,000,000 
f. Newport Cliff Walk - $3,000,000 
g. Agricultural Land Preservation Commission - $5,000,000 
h. Open Space Program - $3,000,000 
i. Forests and Habitat Management - $5,000,000[4]”', '“CULTURAL ARTS AND THE ECONOMY GRANT PROGRAM -$10,000,000 
For purposes of funding for 1:1 matching grants to continue the Cultural Arts and the Economy Grant Program administered by the Rhode Island State Council on the Arts (RISCA) for capital improvement, preservation and renovation projects for public and non-profit artistic centers, performance centers, museums, and cultural art centers located throughout the State of Rhode Island, to be allocated as follows: 
a. Tomaquag Museum - $2,000,000 
b. Newport Contemporary Ballet - $2,000,000 
c. Trinity Repertory Company - $2,000,000 
d. Other funds to be allocated by the Rhode Island State Council on the Arts $4,000,000[4]”']","# Ballot for Kent County, Rhode Island
- **Claudia De La Cruz** (Party for Socialism and Liberation)
## Rhode Island House of Representatives District 28
## Coventry Public Schools school district At-large
## Rhode Island Question 1, Constitutional Convention Question (2024)
“Shall there be a convention to amend or revise the Constitution?[4]”
## Rhode Island Question 2, Higher Education Facilities Bond Measure (2024)
For capital improvements to higher education facilities, to be allocated as follows:
a. University of Rhode Island Biomedical Sciences Building - $87,500,000
b. Rhode Island College Cybersecurity Building - $73,000,000[4]”
## Rhode Island Question 3, Housing Acquisition, Development, and Infrastructure Bond Measure (2024)
To increase the availability of housing, support community revitalization, and promote home ownership, to be allocated as follows:
## Rhode Island Question 4, Environmental and Recreational Infrastructure Bond Measure (2024)
For environmental and recreational purposes, to be allocated as follows:
a. Port of Davisville Infrastructure at Quonset - $15,000,000
c. Brownfields Remediation and Economic Development - $5,000,000
d. Local Recreation Projects - $5,000,000 e. Municipal Resiliency - $10,000,000
## Rhode Island Question 5, Cultural Arts and Economy Grant Program Bond Measure (2024)
“CULTURAL ARTS AND THE ECONOMY GRANT PROGRAM -$10,000,000

For purposes of funding for 1:1 matching grants to continue the Cultural Arts and the Economy Grant Program administered by the Rhode Island State Council on the Arts (RISCA) for capital improvement, preservation and renovation projects for public and non-profit artistic centers, performance centers, museums, and cultural art centers located throughout the State of Rhode Island, to be allocated as follows:
d. Other funds to be allocated by the Rhode Island State Council on the Arts $4,000,000[4]”

## Rhode Island House of Representatives District 28
## Coventry Public Schools school district At-large
## Rhode Island Question 1, Constitutional Convention Question (2024)
“Shall there be a convention to amend or revise the Constitution?[4]”
## Rhode Island Question 2, Higher Education Facilities Bond Measure (2024)
For capital improvements to higher education facilities, to be allocated as follows:
a. University of Rhode Island Biomedical Sciences Building - $87,500,000
b. Rhode Island College Cybersecurity Building - $73,000,000[4]”
## Rhode Island Question 3, Housing Acquisition, Development, and Infrastructure Bond Measure (2024)
To increase the availability of housing, support community revitalization, and promote home ownership, to be allocated as follows:
## Rhode Island Question 4, Environmental and Recreational Infrastructure Bond Measure (2024)
For environmental and recreational purposes, to be allocated as follows:
a. Port of Davisville Infrastructure at Quonset - $15,000,000
c. Brownfields Remediation and Economic Development - $5,000,000
d. Local Recreation Projects - $5,000,000 e. Municipal Resiliency - $10,000,000
## Rhode Island Question 5, Cultural Arts and Economy Grant Program Bond Measure (2024)
“CULTURAL ARTS AND THE ECONOMY GRANT PROGRAM -$10,000,000

For purposes of funding for 1:1 matching grants to continue the Cultural Arts and the Economy Grant Program administered by the Rhode Island State Council on the Arts (RISCA) for capital improvement, preservation and renovation projects for public and non-profit artistic centers, performance centers, museums, and cultural art centers located throughout the State of Rhode Island, to be allocated as follows:
d. Other funds to be allocated by the Rhode Island State Council on the Arts $4,000,000[4]”
